title: Quiz 3: Malaria & Filariasis
description: Comprehensive quiz on the epidemiology, life cycles, and management of Malaria and Filariasis.

questions.question: Which Plasmodium species is responsible for 98% of malaria cases in Kenya and causes 'malignant' malaria?
questions.explanation: P. falciparum is the most prevalent and dangerous malaria parasite in Kenya.
questions.hint: It causes the most severe (malignant) form.

questions.question: Arrange the asexual cycle of the malaria parasite in the human host in the correct sequence:
questions.explanation: Sporozoites move from blood to liver, develop into schizonts, release merozoites to infect RBCs, and some form gametocytes for the next mosquito.

questions.question: Match the typical attack stage of malaria with its hallmark symptoms:

pairs.right: Profuse sweating and rapid temperature drop

questions.explanation: Malaria attacks typically cycle through intense shivering (cold), burning fever (hot), and heavy perspiration (sweating).

questions.question: Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) for malaria in pregnant women involves giving which drug combination?

richContent.content:
Maternal Health Protocol

The first dose is given between 16-24 weeks; the second between 24-36 weeks.

questions.explanation: SP (e.g., Fansidar) is the standard drug for IPT in pregnancy to prevent placental malaria.
questions.hint: It is a single-dose treatment containing Sulfa.

questions.question: What is the name of the tiny worm (nematode) that causes Filariasis (Elephantiasis)?
questions.explanation: Wuchereria bancrofti is the primary parasite causing lymphatic filariasis in the tropical coastal belts.

questions.question: For a definitive diagnosis of Filariasis, when should blood slides for microfilariae ideally be taken?
questions.explanation: The microfilariae show 'nocturnal periodicity,' meaning they are only present in the peripheral blood at night.
questions.hint: They come out when the mosquitoes (Culex) bite at night.

questions.question: Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is effective in killing both the adult worms and the microfilariae in Filariasis.
questions.explanation: DEC (Hetrazan) is the drug of choice as it targets both stages of the parasite.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of 'Complicated' (Severe) Malaria requiring immediate hospitalization? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Severe malaria affects multiple organ systems and is life-threatening without IV treatment.

questions.question: The primary vector for Malaria is the female ___BLANK___ mosquito, while the vector for Filariasis in urban areas is often the ___BLANK___ quinquefasciatus.
questions.explanation: Anopheles transmits malaria; Culex is the main urban vector for filariasis.
questions.hint: Think of the two main mosquito genera.

questions.question: What is the assumed logic behind Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) in malaria endemic areas?

options.text: The patient is likely to be bitten tomorrow
The patient is assumed to be already infected
To kill the mosquitoes in the house

questions.explanation: IPT assumes that in endemic areas, pregnant women likely harbor parasites even if asymptomatic, requiring periodic clearance to protect the fetus.
